convert_nums Module¶

havoc.autoval.lib.test_utils.convert_nums.bytes_to_ints(bytes_string, num_bytes_per_int)[source]¶

Takes a string of space separated bytes (Ex: “ef ab 00 01”) and converts them to ints. This assumes that the least significant bytes come first, and most significant come last.

num_bytes_per_int - The number of consecutive bytes that must be

combined to make a single int.

returns - list of the bytes converted to ints, in order

havoc.autoval.lib.test_utils.convert_nums.int_to_bytes(number, num_bytes)[source]¶

Takes an int, converts to it’s hex equivalent, then splits that into 2 character bytes prefixed with “0x”.

number - The int to convert to hex bytes. num_bytes - The number of bytes you want. The most significant bytes

are padded as “0x00” if they aren’t needed for the number. Ex: (number=16 num_bytes=2) is 0x0010 which

becomes [“0x10”, “0x00”].

returns - a list of the number converted to hex bytes, least significant

bytes first, most significant last.

CstatesRunner Module¶

class havoc.autoval.lib.test_utils.cstates_runner.CstatesRunner(host, args)[source]¶

Bases: havoc.autoval.lib.test_utils.test_utils_base.TestUtilsBase

This test module put the system in various cstates by setting the latency Parameters: sequence: a list of cstates [c0, c1, c3, c6, c7] interval: interval between cstate changes in seconds runtime: total run time

FfmpegRunner Module¶

class havoc.autoval.lib.test_utils.ffmpeg_runner.FfmpegRunner(host, inp_args)[source]¶

Bases: havoc.autoval.lib.test_utils.test_utils_base.TestUtilsBase

“1 input 1 output” ffmpeg test allows to perform and stress video transcoding components by accepting and generating ffmpeg commands from single control file. ffmpeg commands here are being generated with different profile, level, bitrate and scale settings.

__init__(host, inp_args)[source]¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

generate_args(args, test_number, module, scale, profile, level, bitrate, video, cv, gop_type, key_init, bf)[source]¶

fixes the timeout, input and output file args to be run with ffmpeg cmd

@param args: a list of key/value pairs provided by user @param test_number: test number/test command count number @param module: module number @param scale: scale rate to be used for for scaling the inout file @param profile: profile to be used for transcoding @param level: profile level to be used to operate with the input file @param bitrate: bitrate to be used when working with output file @param video: name of the output video file @param cv: “”-c:v” to be used in the ffmpeg command. Current list of -c:v used: h264_vkapi”, “hevc_vkapi”, “vp9_vkapi @return: returns a list of key/value pairs of the updated arguments

input_file_info(host, video)[source]¶

FwUpdateUtil Module¶

class havoc.autoval.lib.test_utils.fw_update_util.FwOpenbmcUtil[source]¶

Bases: object

classmethod _check_setup_requirement_for_downgrade(host, update_method, fw_type_name, enforce_status, fw_ver, fw_ver_src)[source]¶

Check if the user requested previous version is same as the (n-1) version from the kv-store’s image version list. If so downgrade to “previous” version directly, else downgrade to (n-1) version and then to the “previous” version.

classmethod _check_setup_requirement_for_upgrade(host, update_method, fw_type_name, enforce_status, base_fw_ver, base_fw_ver_src, fw_ver, fw_ver_src)[source]¶

We compare the Current version of the BMC and if its below the base or required version of that platform, then upgrade. We do it because vboot-util is not supported for versions older than the base or required version. If its greater than or equal to the base or required version then proceeds with the upgrading to the user requested version.

classmethod _get_minimum_fw_version(host, update_method, fw_type_name)[source]¶

Get the minimum fw version from the fw version json map file

classmethod get_base_version(host, update_method, fw_type_name)[source]¶

Checking if the BMC we are performing test on meets the requirement such as if the version on the BMC is equal or greater than the base required version of that platform. If not, the device is first upgrade to the base-required version of that platform.

As of Nov 2018,

TiogaPass = 4.2 Bryce Canyon = 1.9.2 Yosemitev2 = 3.6

Parameters

  • = contains the host object. (host) –

  • = out of bandsel. (update_method) –

  • = openbmc/bmc (fw_type_name) –

classmethod get_flash_file_from_tmp_dir(path_contents, enforce_status, fw_version)[source]¶

Checks the local directory if it exists or not. If exists then returns the filename of the flash file depending on the hardware enforce status. If folder doesn’t exists then returns False.

Parameters

  • = firmware update version name. (fw_version) –

  • = Contains True or False depending on the value of (enforce_status) – the hardware enforce (HWE) value from the vboot-util. Status is True, if the HWE value is 0x01; else, False

  • = Contents of the destination directory path. (path_contents) –

Example

fw_version = “fby2-v4.6” | “fbtp-v6.0” enforce_status = True | False path_contents = “[‘flash-fby2’,’flash-fby2.locked.signed’,…]”

classmethod openbmc_fwutil_update(host, update_method, fw_type_name, _iter, test_control, fw_version)[source]¶

This function is used to do an OpenBMC upgrade and downgrade using firmware util command. For this test, let us assume the base or required version is 4.4 and the user wants to toggle between 5.0(previous) and 6.0(latest) version and the firmware version map json file contains [4.2, 4.4, 5.0, 5.1, 6.0].

Note: 1. BMC has no issue while upgrading from its current version, but while downgrading it has to downgrade only to the (n-1) version from the output of “cat /mnt/data/kv_store/image_versions.”

2. We compare the current version of the BMC and if its below the base or required version of that platform, then upgrade. We do it because vboot-util is not supported for versions older than the base or required version.

The following are the flows or cases that this OpenBMC test handles:

A. Current Version of BMC is 4.2 kv-store image version’s output after zeroth iteration - [4.2, 4.4, 6.0] 4.2 –> 4.4 –> 6.0 –> 4.4 –> 5.0 –> 6.0 –> 5.0

|__________| |__________| | |

Iter=0 Iter=1 Iter=2 Iter=3

B. Current Version of BMC is 4.4 kv-store image version’s output after zeroth iteration - [4.4, 6.0] 4.4 –> 6.0 –> 4.4 –> 5.0 –> 6.0 –> 5.0

|__________| | |

Iter=0 Iter=1 Iter=2 Iter=3

C. Current Version of BMC is 5.0 kv-store image version’s output after zeroth iteration - [5.0, 6.0] 5.0–> 6.0 –> 5.0 –> 6.0 –> 5.0

| | |

Iter=0 Iter=1 Iter=2 Iter=3

D. Current Version of BMC is 4.6 kv-store image version’s output after zeroth iteration - [4.6, 6.0] 4.6 –> 6.0 –> RTE (during 2nd iteration)


Iter=0

Raise Test Error (RTE), since 4.6 version is not found in the fw_version_map json file.

E. Current Version of BMC is 6.0 and previous version installed on BMC is 5.1 kv_store image version is [5.1, 6.0] 6.0 –> 6.0 (reflashing same BMC version) –> RTE (during 2nd iteration)


Iter=0

RTE, since (n-1) version is greater than the user requested previous_version.

Parameters

  • = contains the host object. (host) –

  • = out of bandsel. (update_method) –

  • = Bios, Nic, OpenBmc etc (fw_type_name) –

  • = current number of the iteration. (_iter) –

  • = contains test control file's json data as dict. (test_control) –

  • = what version of binary, refers to fw_version_map. (fw_version) –

classmethod openbmc_soliton_beam_update(host, fw_type_name, fw_version)[source]¶
classmethod sorting_json_data(json_data)[source]¶

Gets the filtered json file list and sorts through them to provided the minimum version and its file name.

classmethod update_fw_bmc_rom(host, enforce_status, fw_ver_name, fw_ver_src, fw_type)[source]¶

This method does bmc update for the provided fw version name and does rom update only when the enforce status is true, for that fw version of the BMC.

Parameters

  • = contains the host object. (host) –

  • = If hardware enfource status flag is 0x01 then True (enforce_status) – else if 0x00, then False

  • = fw version name of the platform. Eg (fw_ver_name) – fby2-v6.0

  • = fw version source location path. (fw_ver_src) –

classmethod verify_fw_on_oob(host, version)[source]¶

After soliton_beam is completed, Check whether the firmware is updated on the openbmc

class havoc.autoval.lib.test_utils.fw_update_util.FwUpdateUtil[source]¶

Bases: object

classmethod _check_directory_availability_and_delete(host, destination_folder)[source]¶

Checking if the directory is being used by another test. If its being used, then the directory is ignored, else the directory is deleted. Eg: ps | grep <directory> gives default of two results when test diretory is not being used by any other test.

27579 root 2800 S bash -c ps | grep /tmp/havoc 27581 root 2956 S grep /tmp/havoc

classmethod _cleanup_and_retry_copying(host, minimum_space, file_name, control_server_tmpdir, fw_type, file_size)[source]¶

In this method, we get the list of the paths with their memory occupancy. If the havoc system firmware test folder is being not used then they are deleted else not.

To get the list of the folder and their memory occupancy.

Get how much each path and how much memory they are occupying on the BMC. output : :~# du -h /tmp/

199.4M /tmp/havoc_system_fw/havoc_bios 199.4M /tmp/havoc_system_fw 28.0K /tmp/thresh-cache 236.0K /tmp/cache_store 200.0M /tmp/

classmethod _get_bmc_test_folder_path(fw_type=None)[source]¶

This method returns the name of the folder, to hold the binary files during the test, on the destination of the BMC

classmethod check_bic_prerequisite(host, fw_type)[source]¶

To check if the BIC has the bootload version that supports the BIC testing. If not, the BIC bootloader is updated to the latest version and then the test proceeds.

classmethod copy_files_to_bmc(host, file_name, control_server_tmpdir, fw_type, cleanup_bmc=True, available_memoryspace=None, file_size=None)[source]¶

To copy the files into BMC. If there is issue while copying then available memory on the BMC is checked. If there is no space then the havoc related folders on the BMC are deleted only if they are not used by other tests.

classmethod get_fw_binary(host, method, binary_type, binary_ver='latest')[source]¶

Return the complete path of the Bios binary location. @param

host - host object method - Inband or out of bandsel. binary_type - Bios, Nic, OpenBmc etc binary_ver - what version of binary, refers to fw_version_map.

Eg For BIOS the fw_version_map.json looks like below. The code looks for matching Bios binary matching respective version. {

inband:{

“rcd04”:”RCD04.tgz”, “rcd05”:”RCD05.tgz”, “latest”: “rcd05”, “previous”: “rcd04”, “stable”: “rcd04”

}, oob:{

“rcd04”:”RCD04.tgz”, “rcd05”:”RCD05.tgz”, “latest”: “rcd05”, “previous”: “rcd04”, “stable”: “rcd04”

}

}

classmethod get_fw_test_file_name(binary_source, fw_version, fw_type, enforce_status=False, raise_error=False)[source]¶

This method is used to check if the folder exists in the local directory, else returns False. If exists then check for the binary or flash file of the firmware version and return the file name, else raise Exception.

start_clients(server, clients)[source]¶
start_iperf(server, client, role, port)[source]¶

starts iperf server/client. Starts iperf server on default port 5201 if no port information is provided for 1 to 1 connection. For multihost, checks if no. of tcp ports is equal to no of client to creat 1 to n connection and start server on each port. If no port information found start iperf server incremental from 5201 port

start_iperf_client(server, client, port)[source]¶
start_iperf_server(server, port)[source]¶

stop_server(server)[source]¶
update_iperf_out(key, hostname, data)[source]¶
validate_bandwidth(actual, expected, msg)[source]¶
validate_bandwidths(hosts, expected_bw)[source]¶
validate_ethtool_data(host, eth_before, eth_after)[source]¶
lock = <unlocked _thread.lock object>¶
ports = {}¶
havoc.autoval.lib.test_utils.iperf.ETH_TOOL_FIELDS = {'bnxt': ['rx_fcs_err_frames', 'rx_align_err_frames'], 'mlx': ['rx_discards_phy', 'rx_packets_phy', 'tx_packets_phy', 'link_down_events_phy', 'rx_out_of_buffer', 'rx_packets', 'tx_packets', 'rx_bytes', 'tx_bytes']}¶
http://software.es.net/iperf/

Server or Client: -p, –port # server port to listen on/connect to -f, –format [kmgKMG] format to report: Kbits, Mbits, KBytes, MBytes -i, –interval # seconds between periodic bandwidth reports -F, –file name xmit/recv the specified file -A, –affinity n/n,m set CPU affinity -B, –bind <host> bind to a specific interface -V, –verbose more detailed output -J, –json output in JSON format –logfile f send output to a log file –forceflush force flushing output at every interval -d, –debug emit debugging output -v, –version show version information and quit -h, –help show this message and quit

Server specific:
-s, --server

run in server mode

-D, --daemon

run the server as a daemon

-I, --pidfile file

write PID file

-1, --one-off

handle one client connection then exit

Client specific:
-c, --client

<host> run in client mode, connecting to <host>

-u, --udp

use UDP rather than TCP

-b, –bandwidth #[KMG][/#] target bandwidth in bits/sec (0 for unlimited)

(default 1 Mbit/sec for UDP, unlimited for TCP) (optional slash and packet count for burst mode)

–fq-rate #[KMG] enable fair-queuing based socket pacing in

bits/sec (Linux only)

-t, --time

# time in seconds to transmit for (default 10 secs)

-n, --bytes

#[KMG] number of bytes to transmit (instead of -t)

-k, –blockcount #[KMG] number of blocks (packets) to transmit (instead of -t or -n) -l, –len #[KMG] length of buffer to read or write

(default 128 KB for TCP, dynamic or 1 for UDP)

--cport

<port> bind to a specific client port ( TCP and UDP, default: ephemeral port)

-P, --parallel

# number of parallel client streams to run

-R, --reverse

run in reverse mode (server sends, client receives)

-w, --window

#[KMG] set window size / socket buffer size

-C, --congestion <algo>

set TCP congestion control algorithm ( Linux and FreeBSD only)

-M, --set-mss

# set TCP/SCTP maximum segment size (MTU - 40 bytes)

-N, --no-delay

set TCP/SCTP no delay, disabling Nagle’s Algorithm

-4, --version4

only use IPv4

-6, --version6

only use IPv6

-S, --tos N

set the IP ‘type of service’

-L, --flowlabel N

set the IPv6 flow label (only supported on Linux)

-Z, --zerocopy

use a ‘zero copy’ method of sending data

-O, --omit N

omit the first n seconds

-T, --title str

prefix every output line with this string

--get-server-output

get results from server

--udp-counters-64bit

use 64-bit counters in UDP test packets

[KMG] indicates options that support a K/M/G suffix for kilo-, mega-, or giga-

Type

Supported iperf3 options

Type

  • iperf3 homepage at

start_SOL_on_logged_screen_session()[source]¶

Starts a screen session on a remote machine (a machine which is not the server under test) and activates the SOL session on it. The screen session has logging enabled, so all SOL output will be saved into a screen log file.

get_test_memory(mem_perc, total_mem=True)[source]¶

Returns a percentage of the total free memory in MB using free -m based on the “memory_perc” argument. If total_mem is specified returns the percentage of the “total” column, otherwise percentage of the “free” column ‘free -m’ output:-

total used free shared buff/cache available

Mem: 57244 5618 1522 253 50103 49809

havoc.autoval.lib.test_utils.utils.find_in_nested_dict(nested_dict, key)[source]¶
